Edward Mitri Karkar (1932 – December 22, 2013) was a Palestinian-American engineer and entrepreneur, best known for his pioneering contributions to satellite communications and for founding Karkar Electronics.
Biography
Karkar was born in Jaffa, Palestine, in 1932. His family fled the region during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War and later resettled in the United States. He pursued engineering studies at the University of California, Berkeley and later worked at Stanford University, where he began focusing on telecommunications technologies.
Career
Karkar Electronics
In 1959, Karkar founded Karkar Electronics in San Francisco. The company specialized in producing advanced components for satellite earth stations, including microwave filters, high-density multiplexers, and baseband systems.
Karkar Electronics supplied infrastructure to both government and private entities, including Raytheon, AT&T, MCI Inc., the United States Department of Defense, and NATO. Its technologies were also deployed in countries such as Sudan, Oman, and Saudi Arabia.
ERAS Holdings
Following Karkar’s retirement, his legacy was continued by his son, Andrei Karkar, through the family investment firm ERAS Holdings, which focuses on emerging and sustainable technologies.
Personal Life
Karkar was married to Russian ballerina Natalia Makarova. Together they had a son, Andrei Karkar. Edward Karkar passed away on December 22, 2013, in San Francisco, California.
